item.title: Public-key Cryptography
item.description: Asymmetric cryptography involves a pair of keys, one for encrypting (public) another for decrypting (private). One is private ($K^-$), the other is public ($K^+$).

item.title: Peer to peer
item.description: In contrast to client-server models, peer-to-peer systems are [[thoughts/decentralization|decentralized]] [[thoughts/Network Theory|networks]] with no privileged nodes. Each node performs the same roles as any other.

item.title: HTTP
item.description: Main method of communication at the Application Layer for the web. A state-transfer protocol. See also: [[thoughts/Braid HTTP]] for HTTP as state-synchronization

item.title: TCP
item.description: [[thoughts/Transport Layer|Transport layer protocol]] When a host requires assurance that the remote end has actually received the data it sends. But instead of requesting a signature at the remote end, TCP requires an acknowledgement be returned

item.title: Application Layer (Networking)
item.description: Layer 1, the layer above the Transport Layer Application/Presentation/Session layer Unit: Data Responsibilities: human-computer interaction layer, where applications can access the network services (includes [[thoughts/encryption|encryption]], connection, port, and session management)

item.title: ARP
item.description: Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) Purpose: links the Network Layer (IP address) with the link layer (MAC address) Case: A wants tot send a datagram to B, but A doesn’t know B’s MAC address

item.title: DHCP
item.description: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol so they can join a network. Assigns IP addresses to hosts. Main reason was when people started moving devices across networks

item.title: DNS
item.description: Domain name: an identification string that defines a realm of administrative autonomy, authority, or control within the Internet. DNS currently has ~300 million DNS registrations.

item.title: IP Addresses
item.description: IP addresses are 32 bits (4 bytes) split into 4 chunks. Obviously $2^{32}$ is an incredibly large address space so we compress the table using IP prefixes.

item.title: Link Layer
item.description: Layer 4, the layer below the Network Layer and layer above the [[Physical Layer]] Hardware Unit: Frame Responsibilities: Routes frames to adjacent machines (“direct” connection) on a local area network (LAN).

item.title: NAT
item.description: Network Address Translation Both network and transport layer (violation of abstraction/layering) More devices than IP addresses! What do we do?

item.title: Network Layer (IP)
item.description: Layer 3, the layer below the Transport Layer and layer above the Link Layer Unit: Packet (datagram) Responsibilities: Routes packet through routers to destination machine (not necessary if two devices are on the same network) Two main functions Forwarding: move packets from router’s input to appropriate router output (process of getting through a single interchange) Routing: determine route taken by packets from source to destination (process of planning trip from source to destination) Packet Definition Contains information about the packet itself (metadata) and the body/content

item.title: Physical Layer
item.description: Layer 5, layer below the Link Layer Hardware Unit: Bits Responsibilities: Encodes data appropriately for the physical medium

item.title: Protocols
item.description: Defines: Roles of communicating entities Format of messages Order of messages Actions taken on the transmission, receipt of a message, or other event Protocols as State Machines A fully-defined protocol must provide a proper action for any event in any state.
